intro: Chamaesyce hirtula, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, which includes many species with unique floral structures. The plant typically grows as a low, spreading shrub with hairy stems and small, alternate leaves. Its flowers are unisexual, with separate male and female flowers on the same plant, a characteristic known as monoecious. Chamaesyce hirtula is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and open woodlands.
